description: From Middle English glowen, from Old English glōwan, from Proto-Germanic *glōaną, from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰel-. Cognate with Saterland Frisian gloie, glöie, gluuje, West Frisian gloeie, Dutch gloeien, German glühen, Danish and Norwegian glo, Icelandic glóa. See also glass.

entries.meaning: The light given off by a glowing object.
The condition of being passionate or having warm feelings.
The brilliance or warmth of color in an environment or on a person (especially one's face).
examples: He had a bright red glow on his face.

verbs.description: glow (third-person singular simple present glows, present participle glowing, simple past glowed or (nonstandard) glew, past participle glowed or (nonstandard) glown)

entries.meaning: To emit light as if heated.
examples: The fire was still glowing after ten hours.
Iron glows red hot when heated to near its melting point.
After their workout, the gymnasts' faces were glowing red.
The zealots glowed with religious fervor.

entries.meaning: To gaze especially passionately at something.

examples: The new baby's room glows with bright, loving colors.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To feel hot; to have a burning sensation, as of the skin, from friction, exercise, etc.; to burn.
examples: Did not his temples glow / In the same sultry winds and scorching heats?

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Internet slang) To be related to or part of an (chiefly online) undercover sting operation, especially by American federal agencies.
(Internet slang, alt-right) to expose someone to the authorities.
(Internet slang, alt-right) to create a threatening online post that may involve violence, and look suspicious enough to attract a police investigation.
